issue.title: Triads in key
issue.body:
Hi.

Is there any reason why the triads were removed from the Key package?
like 
`Key.majorKey("C").triads`

comment.body:
It's now on [mode](https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/tree/main/packages/mode#triadsmodename-string-tonic-string--string) package:

```js
import { Mode } from "tonal";
Mode.triads("major", "C") // => ["C", "Dm", ...]
```

Maybe `Key` could expose a similar function... let me think about it.

issue.title: Tonal.Chord.detect(["D", "F", "C"]) empty result
issue.body:
Hey guitar player here!
We sometimes omit the 5th from a chord to make it more manageable to play.
Having tonic, 3rd and 7th should be enough to characterize a chord and identify a Dmin7. (other implementations do [here](https://www.oolimo.com/guitarchords/analyze) and [here](https://www.scales-chords.com/findnotes_en.php?n1=D&n2=F&n3=C&n4=&n5=&n6=))
Since I'm transcribing from tabs in realtime, a workaround on the input is not really manageable for my specific use case

I'm using tonal 4.6.0 pulled from jsdelivr CDN [here](https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@tonaljs/tonal@4.6.0/browser/tonal.min.js)

~~If you're happy with it, I can open you a PR on https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/blob/master/packages/chord-type/data.ts#L24
adding `["1P 3m 7m", "minor seventh", "m7 min7 mi7 -7"],` just right after that line.~~

Guitar world will thank you :)

edit: actually you could just programmatically infer all the alternative versions by dynamically populating a version of that array with the 5P removed

issue.title: Get 7 chords for a given scale
issue.body:
with the Key.majorKey function a list of the seven chords for that key are provided in the chords property such as 

```
chords: [
    "Cmaj7",
    "Dm7",
    "Em7",
    "Fmaj7",
    "G7",
    "Am7",
    "Bm7b5"
],
```

With one each rooted off each note of the scale. 

Can the same thing be gotten for a given scale such as C dorian 
I have tried  Scale.get("C dorian ") but it does not provide an equivalent

comment.body:
Yes, this is because four notes triadic chords are not a property of every scale. Anyway, keep this open to see what alternatives we could figure it out. 

For example, I can imagine a function that given the chord degrees, it returns the note names. Something like:
```
Scale.getDegrees("C major", [1, 3, 5, 7]) // => ['C', 'E', 'G', 'B']
```

Thoughts?

issue.title: Tonal is not defined
issue.body:
My implementation of Tonal has recently broken - I'm sure it was working before! 

`Uncaught ReferenceError: Tonal is not defined`

So trying to create the simplest html page, I'm still getting the same error:  

```
<html>
  <head>
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/tonal/browser/tonal.min.js"></script>
<script>
  console.log(Tonal.Key.minorKey("Ab"));
</script>
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

```

comment.body:
Yes, providing a browser version of tonal is probably not a good idea nowadays. Probably it would be better to use one service (so it's probably that I remove that in next major version). 

In a quick look, it seems the `https://esm.run/tonal` is a good alternative for esm (and deno) compatible modules, but I'm unsure about `<script ... >` tags. Thoughs?

Anyway, very cool project @5paceb0i  Have you considered to add it to the main README?

review.body:
Thanks for the PR! A couple of things:

- It would be nice to add some documentation at the README
- As you can probably [read](https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/issues/348#issuecomment-1329462394) I was reluctant to add this kind of signatures... The problem that I see is that now any fractional can be parsed as a time signature, and I'm not sure (I don't know about irrational time signatures enough) that all them are valid time signatures... So I'd like to find (if any) an example of a valid fraction that is not a valid time signature, and add it to the tests... For example, is `123/231934` a valid irrational time signature? I don't know... (but my music theory intuition says no)

issue.title: error when trying to get TimeSignature with lower > 9
issue.body:
> TimeSignature.get('12/10')
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'split')
    at parse (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:62:19)
    at parse (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:55:12)
    at Object.get (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:48:20)

comment.body:
Of course, this should not throw in this case.

Said that, this is not an `irregular` time signature, but an `irrational one` (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_signature#Irrational_meters). I was reluctant to introduce that kind of signatures because I think they are very artificial, very very rare, and could give the idea that any fraction is suitable for a time signature.

Anyway, since they are mentioned in wikipedia, I think we could implement it... thoughts?

Bumps [ansi-regex](https://github.com/chalk/ansi-regex) from 5.0.0 to 5.0.1.
Release notes

Sourced from ansi-regex's releases.

v5.0.1

Fixes (backport of 6.0.1 to v5)

This is a backport of the minor ReDos vulnerability in ansi-regex@<6.0.1, as requested in #38.

  • Fix ReDoS in certain cases (#37) You are only really affected if you run the regex on untrusted user input in a server context, which it's very unlikely anyone is doing, since this regex is mainly used in command-line tools.

CVE-2021-3807

https://github.com/chalk/ansi-regex/compare/v5.0.0..v5.0.1

issue.title: Triads in key
issue.body:
Hi.

Is there any reason why the triads were removed from the Key package?
like 
`Key.majorKey("C").triads`

comment.body:
It's now on [mode](https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/tree/main/packages/mode#triadsmodename-string-tonic-string--string) package:

```js
import { Mode } from "tonal";
Mode.triads("major", "C") // => ["C", "Dm", ...]
```

Maybe `Key` could expose a similar function... let me think about it.

issue.title: Tonal.Chord.detect(["D", "F", "C"]) empty result
issue.body:
Hey guitar player here!
We sometimes omit the 5th from a chord to make it more manageable to play.
Having tonic, 3rd and 7th should be enough to characterize a chord and identify a Dmin7. (other implementations do [here](https://www.oolimo.com/guitarchords/analyze) and [here](https://www.scales-chords.com/findnotes_en.php?n1=D&n2=F&n3=C&n4=&n5=&n6=))
Since I'm transcribing from tabs in realtime, a workaround on the input is not really manageable for my specific use case

I'm using tonal 4.6.0 pulled from jsdelivr CDN [here](https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@tonaljs/tonal@4.6.0/browser/tonal.min.js)

~~If you're happy with it, I can open you a PR on https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/blob/master/packages/chord-type/data.ts#L24
adding `["1P 3m 7m", "minor seventh", "m7 min7 mi7 -7"],` just right after that line.~~

Guitar world will thank you :)

edit: actually you could just programmatically infer all the alternative versions by dynamically populating a version of that array with the 5P removed

issue.title: Get 7 chords for a given scale
issue.body:
with the Key.majorKey function a list of the seven chords for that key are provided in the chords property such as 

```
chords: [
    "Cmaj7",
    "Dm7",
    "Em7",
    "Fmaj7",
    "G7",
    "Am7",
    "Bm7b5"
],
```

With one each rooted off each note of the scale. 

Can the same thing be gotten for a given scale such as C dorian 
I have tried  Scale.get("C dorian ") but it does not provide an equivalent

comment.body:
Yes, this is because four notes triadic chords are not a property of every scale. Anyway, keep this open to see what alternatives we could figure it out. 

For example, I can imagine a function that given the chord degrees, it returns the note names. Something like:
```
Scale.getDegrees("C major", [1, 3, 5, 7]) // => ['C', 'E', 'G', 'B']
```

Thoughts?

issue.title: Tonal is not defined
issue.body:
My implementation of Tonal has recently broken - I'm sure it was working before! 

`Uncaught ReferenceError: Tonal is not defined`

So trying to create the simplest html page, I'm still getting the same error:  

```
<html>
  <head>
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/tonal/browser/tonal.min.js"></script>
<script>
  console.log(Tonal.Key.minorKey("Ab"));
</script>
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

```

comment.body:
Yes, providing a browser version of tonal is probably not a good idea nowadays. Probably it would be better to use one service (so it's probably that I remove that in next major version). 

In a quick look, it seems the `https://esm.run/tonal` is a good alternative for esm (and deno) compatible modules, but I'm unsure about `<script ... >` tags. Thoughs?

Anyway, very cool project @5paceb0i  Have you considered to add it to the main README?

review.body:
Thanks for the PR! A couple of things:

- It would be nice to add some documentation at the README
- As you can probably [read](https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/issues/348#issuecomment-1329462394) I was reluctant to add this kind of signatures... The problem that I see is that now any fractional can be parsed as a time signature, and I'm not sure (I don't know about irrational time signatures enough) that all them are valid time signatures... So I'd like to find (if any) an example of a valid fraction that is not a valid time signature, and add it to the tests... For example, is `123/231934` a valid irrational time signature? I don't know... (but my music theory intuition says no)

issue.title: error when trying to get TimeSignature with lower > 9
issue.body:
> TimeSignature.get('12/10')
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'split')
    at parse (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:62:19)
    at parse (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:55:12)
    at Object.get (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:48:20)

comment.body:
Of course, this should not throw in this case.

Said that, this is not an `irregular` time signature, but an `irrational one` (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_signature#Irrational_meters). I was reluctant to introduce that kind of signatures because I think they are very artificial, very very rare, and could give the idea that any fraction is suitable for a time signature.

Anyway, since they are mentioned in wikipedia, I think we could implement it... thoughts?

pull_request.title: Bump ansi-regex from 5.0.0 to 5.0.1
pull_request.body:
Bumps [ansi-regex](https://github.com/chalk/ansi-regex) from 5.0.0 to 5.0.1.
Release notes

Sourced from ansi-regex's releases.

v5.0.1

Fixes (backport of 6.0.1 to v5)

This is a backport of the minor ReDos vulnerability in ansi-regex@<6.0.1, as requested in #38.

  • Fix ReDoS in certain cases (#37) You are only really affected if you run the regex on untrusted user input in a server context, which it's very unlikely anyone is doing, since this regex is mainly used in command-line tools.

CVE-2021-3807

https://github.com/chalk/ansi-regex/compare/v5.0.0..v5.0.1

Thank you @​yetingli for the patch and reproduction case!

issue.title: Triads in key
issue.body:
Hi.

Is there any reason why the triads were removed from the Key package?
like 
`Key.majorKey("C").triads`

comment.body:
It's now on [mode](https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/tree/main/packages/mode#triadsmodename-string-tonic-string--string) package:

```js
import { Mode } from "tonal";
Mode.triads("major", "C") // => ["C", "Dm", ...]
```

Maybe `Key` could expose a similar function... let me think about it.

issue.title: Tonal.Chord.detect(["D", "F", "C"]) empty result
issue.body:
Hey guitar player here!
We sometimes omit the 5th from a chord to make it more manageable to play.
Having tonic, 3rd and 7th should be enough to characterize a chord and identify a Dmin7. (other implementations do [here](https://www.oolimo.com/guitarchords/analyze) and [here](https://www.scales-chords.com/findnotes_en.php?n1=D&n2=F&n3=C&n4=&n5=&n6=))
Since I'm transcribing from tabs in realtime, a workaround on the input is not really manageable for my specific use case

I'm using tonal 4.6.0 pulled from jsdelivr CDN [here](https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@tonaljs/tonal@4.6.0/browser/tonal.min.js)

~~If you're happy with it, I can open you a PR on https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/blob/master/packages/chord-type/data.ts#L24
adding `["1P 3m 7m", "minor seventh", "m7 min7 mi7 -7"],` just right after that line.~~

Guitar world will thank you :)

edit: actually you could just programmatically infer all the alternative versions by dynamically populating a version of that array with the 5P removed

issue.title: Get 7 chords for a given scale
issue.body:
with the Key.majorKey function a list of the seven chords for that key are provided in the chords property such as 

```
chords: [
    "Cmaj7",
    "Dm7",
    "Em7",
    "Fmaj7",
    "G7",
    "Am7",
    "Bm7b5"
],
```

With one each rooted off each note of the scale. 

Can the same thing be gotten for a given scale such as C dorian 
I have tried  Scale.get("C dorian ") but it does not provide an equivalent

comment.body:
Yes, this is because four notes triadic chords are not a property of every scale. Anyway, keep this open to see what alternatives we could figure it out. 

For example, I can imagine a function that given the chord degrees, it returns the note names. Something like:
```
Scale.getDegrees("C major", [1, 3, 5, 7]) // => ['C', 'E', 'G', 'B']
```

Thoughts?

issue.title: Tonal is not defined
issue.body:
My implementation of Tonal has recently broken - I'm sure it was working before! 

`Uncaught ReferenceError: Tonal is not defined`

So trying to create the simplest html page, I'm still getting the same error:  

```
<html>
  <head>
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/tonal/browser/tonal.min.js"></script>
<script>
  console.log(Tonal.Key.minorKey("Ab"));
</script>
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

```

comment.body:
Yes, providing a browser version of tonal is probably not a good idea nowadays. Probably it would be better to use one service (so it's probably that I remove that in next major version). 

In a quick look, it seems the `https://esm.run/tonal` is a good alternative for esm (and deno) compatible modules, but I'm unsure about `<script ... >` tags. Thoughs?

Anyway, very cool project @5paceb0i  Have you considered to add it to the main README?

review.body:
Thanks for the PR! A couple of things:

- It would be nice to add some documentation at the README
- As you can probably [read](https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/issues/348#issuecomment-1329462394) I was reluctant to add this kind of signatures... The problem that I see is that now any fractional can be parsed as a time signature, and I'm not sure (I don't know about irrational time signatures enough) that all them are valid time signatures... So I'd like to find (if any) an example of a valid fraction that is not a valid time signature, and add it to the tests... For example, is `123/231934` a valid irrational time signature? I don't know... (but my music theory intuition says no)

issue.title: error when trying to get TimeSignature with lower > 9
issue.body:
> TimeSignature.get('12/10')
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'split')
    at parse (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:62:19)
    at parse (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:55:12)
    at Object.get (@tonaljs/time-signature/dist/index.js:48:20)

comment.body:
Of course, this should not throw in this case.

Said that, this is not an `irregular` time signature, but an `irrational one` (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_signature#Irrational_meters). I was reluctant to introduce that kind of signatures because I think they are very artificial, very very rare, and could give the idea that any fraction is suitable for a time signature.

Anyway, since they are mentioned in wikipedia, I think we could implement it... thoughts?

pull_request.title: Bump ansi-regex from 5.0.0 to 5.0.1
pull_request.body:
Bumps [ansi-regex](https://github.com/chalk/ansi-regex) from 5.0.0 to 5.0.1.
Release notes

Sourced from ansi-regex's releases.

v5.0.1

Fixes (backport of 6.0.1 to v5)

This is a backport of the minor ReDos vulnerability in ansi-regex@<6.0.1, as requested in #38.

  • Fix ReDoS in certain cases (#37) You are only really affected if you run the regex on untrusted user input in a server context, which it's very unlikely anyone is doing, since this regex is mainly used in command-line tools.

CVE-2021-3807

https://github.com/chalk/ansi-regex/compare/v5.0.0..v5.0.1

Thank you @​yetingli for the patch and reproduction case!

Commits
  • a9babce 5.0.1
  • 4657833 fix incorrect format
  • c3c0b3f Fix potential ReDoS (#37)
  • 178363b Move to GitHub Actions (#35)
  • 0755e66 Add @​Qix- to funding.yml
  • See full diff in compare view
